column1: {{quote|Each new Steward indeed took office with the oath 'to hold rod and rule in the name of the king
column2: until he shall return.' But these soon became words of ritual little heeded
column3: for the Stewards exercised all the power of the kings. Yet many in Gondor still believed that a king would indeed return in some time to come; and some remembered the ancient line of the North
column4:
which it was rumoured still lived on in the shadows. But against such thoughts the Ruling Stewards hardened their hearts.
Nonetheless the Stewards never sat on the ancient throne; and they wore no crown
column5: and held no sceptre. They bore a white rod only as the token of their office; and their banner was white without charge; but the royal banner had been sable
column6: upon which was displayed a white tree in blossom beneath seven stars.|[[The Return of the King]]

column1: The first volume of Tolkien's greatly acclaimed epic was first published July 29
column3: the second  on November 11 of the same year
column4: and the final volume on October 20
column5: 1955. They have inspired generations of readers ever since
column6:
and millions of new admirers are growing acquainted with the story because of the very popular motion picture adaptations directed by Peter Jackson.
These selections of quotations are designed to give but a taste of the what many hail as the magnificence of the tale
column7:
and some of the striking language employed within it.
Like many great books it is a work that many read many times for the beauty of its language and its themes
column8: and these quotations are intended to provide a rich sampling as to why
column9: without providing too extensive an indication of the plot of the story itself— and also to provide those who have read it with a collection of small reminders of what makes it so memorable. Like all the greatest literature it is full of both triumphs and tragedies
column10: with complex connections and associations that do not always become apparent on the first reading
column11: nor even with many readings thereafter. To emphasize the fair use nature of these quotations this footnote and links to the official publishers of the books occur on all the pages for quotations from ''The Lord of the Rings''.
